Award.AwardTitle: CAREER (IDBR): Novel Quantitative Second-Harmonic Generation Microscope for Fundamental Study of Collagen Fibers in the Eye
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this CAREER award is to develop a non invasive, quantitative microscopy method with enhanced spatial resolution and depth penetration for the study of collagen fibers in living biological systems such as the cornea. The method, second-harmonic generation microscopy, is a nonlinear optical process that allows detailed imaging without the need for stains or contrast agents. The microscope would combine second harmonic nonlinear scattering with three dimensional control of light polarization and software analysis methods. The resulting system will enable noninvasive determination of the spatial organization of collagen fibers, allowing differentiation between fibrillar collagen types and assessment of collagen fiber spatial orientation and spacing.
The educational objective of this award is to promote optical science and engineering education to the general public. To accomplish this, an online educational YouTube series ("Photonics TV") on optics for high-school and college students will be established. A hands-on optics module ("Optics Circus") will be developed for middle school students, and a Minority Contributions to Science and Technology Series set for use in the local community. More information is available at http://probe.mechse.illinois.edu

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this 5-year CAREER research award a unique, quantitative second-harmonic generation (Q-SHG) microscope was developed. The Q-SHG microscope provides high-resolution, high-contrast 3D images of the collagen fibers that are common in mammals. An additional advantage is that the Q-SHG microscope permits quantitation of the collagen fiber organization. More than half a dozen peer-reviewed journal articles and a dozen conference presentations directly resulted from this work. In one example application, the Q-SHG microscope is used to quantify the collagen fiber spatial organization of pig cortical bone as a function of age, which is important in facilitating understanding of certain bone diseases such as osteoporosis. As another example, the technique is used applied to investigate the 3D collagen fiber network in the cervical microstructure; the impact of the impact of the cervical microenvironment on preterm labor is not well understood but is believed to be essential to elucidating the onset of preterm labor in some women. In yet another example, the Q-SHG microscope is used to assess tendon injury; this work was featured in the Editor’s Choice segment in Science (special Insights of the Decade & Breakthrough of the Year issue in 2010). In addition to the aforementioned technical achievements, the project also resulted in several educational and outreach milestones. Theses or final projects for at least 1 Ph.D. and a half dozen M.S. students also resulted from this project. Project materials were integrated into one advanced graduate course in optics, and a combined senior-graduate course in general optics. In addition, during the project period, hands-on interactive science demos were developed and presented at local middle and high schools.
